params.text:
An instructive text is a text that instructor tells you how to do something. For example: a recipe instructs you how to cook something.

A leaflet that comes with a piece of furniture tells you how to put it together or take care of it.

Instructive texts sometimes

  • Use verbs, placed at the beginning of the sentence, that tell you to do something; the language is direct and unnecessary words are left out
  • Use 'must' and 'must not'.
  • Use diagrams or pictures to help understanding.
  • Use numbered or bulleted points.

Source: bbc.co.uk/skillswise

Here are the steps in this activity

1. You will first discover a series of instructive texts about the environment

2. You will work together in pairs or small groups to gather answers about each text

3. In class or in a collaborative document, you will then share your main conclusions to draft a list of all the conventions relevant to this particular text type

4. Your next step will be to translate (FR>EN) a short text applying these conventions as best you can

5. Finally, you will be able to take a critical look at an MT output for this text.

params.text:
Text 1. How To Go Zero Waste In 2 Steps

Step 1. Just Say No to Crap

To truly go zero, one must commit to refusing to allow crap into your life.  Before you buy anything (or accept any freebie) ask: is it designed to be used just once, or for a short time, and then got rid of?  Where did it come from and what happens to it when I’ve finished with it? Who produced it and in what conditions? Where do gadgets go when they die? How much do I really need one of these anyway?

A question I’m often asked is ‘couldn’t I just use x, then recycle or compost it?’ The answer is yes, it will stop it from going to landfill, if that’s what you’re aiming to do. But consider the resources that went into producing the item before you bought it – extracting the raw materials, manufacturing it, transporting it…..every time we dispose of something and buy more we repeat this cycle.

Forget about disposability and think instead about value. Why invest your money in something that you expect to use only briefly then get rid of? Disposing of things just means you’ll have to go back to the shops and buy more. Who do you suppose benefits from this? Make life easy for yourself.

Read the full text here: https://thezerowaster.com/how-to-go-zero/

Text 1. How To Go Zero Waste In 5 Steps

Step 2: Make the Changes That Will Have The Biggest Impact

I’m not going to tell you to bring your own reusable cups and bags, because you’ve already thought of that, and anyway, why start so small? Unless you use a lot of single-use cups and bags, these probably aren’t your biggest areas of impact.

For best results, start with the changes that will make the most difference. Take a step back and consider everything you buy that doesn’t last that long, remembering that actual stuff takes more resources to produce than rubbish. Perhaps it’s gadgets that now sit unused in some box, fashion you buy but hardly wear, or leisure equipment that spends most of the time in the loft. All of these come with their own carbon and water footprints, among other environmental impacts too long to list here, and may well have been made using exploitative labour practices. So consider all of these as well as the single-use disposables filling up landfill sacks.

If you have a lot of things sitting around going to waste, think about passing it on to someone who can use it. You get lovely clutter-free space,  your recipient gets stuff cheaply or for free, and between you you have reduced the demand for more new stuff to be produced.

Then, have a look inside your bin and see what it’s mostly full of. Ask yourself why. And start from there.

Read the full text here: https://thezerowaster.com/how-to-go-zero/

solution.sample:
1. This text was written to help people reduce their waste to a minimum. It might be a testimony written by someone who has done this before, or a word of advice given by a specialist. It was published on a dedicated website (The zero waster) and there are two parts, corresponding to the two recommended steps.
2. The register is untechnical and rather informal (e.g. crap). The author refers to himself with the first person and addresses the reader with the second person, and often uses the imperative to encourage the reader to do the recommended actions. There are few impersonal verb forms (one must commit, and the passive) and more personal forms as the author is trying to convince readers and get them to act.

params.taskDescription:
Read text 1 and answer the following questions:

1. Background

  • What is the purpose of this text?
  • Who wrote it? On what type of website was it published?
  • What are the main parts of the document?

2. Language

  • What is the register? (formal, informal, colloquial, technical...)
  • How does the author refer to himself/herself? How does the author address his/her readers?
  • Identify the impersonal forms in your document. Are these forms used to convey a certain type of information?
  • Write down 5 or 6 phrases or vocabulary words that you can use to translate this type of text.

params.text:
Comment passer au zéro déchet en deux étapes

 

  Étape 1. Dites simplement non à la merde  

 

Pour vraiment aller à zéro, il faut s'engager à refuser de laisser entrer la merde dans votre vie. Avant d'acheter quoi que ce soit (ou d'accepter un cadeau), demandez-vous : est-il conçu pour être utilisé une seule fois, ou pendant une courte période, puis s'en débarrasser ? D'où vient-il et que devient-il quand j'en ai fini ? Qui l'a produit et dans quelles conditions ? Où vont les gadgets quand ils meurent ? Combien ai-je vraiment besoin d'un de ceux-ci de toute façon? Une question que l'on me pose souvent est "ne pourrais-je pas simplement utiliser x, puis le recycler ou le composter?" La réponse est oui, cela l'empêchera d'aller à la décharge, si c'est ce que vous visez. Mais considérez les ressources qui ont été nécessaires à la production de l'article avant de l'acheter - extraire les matières premières, le fabriquer, le transporter... chaque fois que nous nous débarrassons de quelque chose et que nous en achetons plus, nous répétons ce cycle. Oubliez le jetable et pensez plutôt à la valeur. Pourquoi investir votre argent dans quelque chose que vous ne comptez utiliser que brièvement puis dont vous vous débarrassez ? Se débarrasser des choses signifie simplement que vous devrez retourner dans les magasins et en acheter plus. À qui pensez-vous que ça profite ? Facilitez-vous la vie.

solution.sample:
- The French word "merde" is unacceptable here, being much more informal than "crap" in the source text.
- "aller à zéro" is not a common collocation in French, it sounds weird and might be difficult to understand even in a dedicated website
- the questions could be made shorter and easier to read, so as to appeal more to the reader.
- the use of imperatives and of the verb "il faut" also need to be carefully considered: would they produce a successful text?
